III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth does not always feel safe at facility and indicated they were
sexually abused by two staff members. The abuse was described
as two different staff members not knocking on the bathroom door
and walking in on the youth. There was no touching reported.
Youth filled out a RR complaint, but there was no response.
Investigation A phone message was left with Complainant, who is a staff
member, on December 6, 2023, with no response.
Manager was interviewed face to face on December 6, 2023.
Manager reported being aware of the allegations made by Youth
A and Staff 3 reporting the information. Manager stated he did not
know who the female staff Youth A referenced but was aware of
the situation with Staff 1. Manager confirmed Youth A completed
a Recipient Rights Complaint on Staff 1. Manager stated Staff 1 is
now working on a different unit from Youth A.
2

Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
December 6, 2023. Youth A reported two different staff, on
separate occasions, walked into her room to complete checks on
Youth A without announcing themselves or knocking on the door.
Youth A described being in the shower when Staff 2 entered her
room. Youth A stated it was the only time this occurred with Staff
2 and is not aware of Staff 2 entering any other youths’ room
without announcing herself or knocking on the door. Youth A
stated she was in the shower with the water running but would
have heard Staff 2 announce herself and knock on the door.
Youth A stated she had the door open, so she stuck her head out
around the wall and yelled at Staff 2 for not knocking. Youth A
stated Staff 2 told Youth A she knocked three or four times and,
announced herself. Youth A reported Staff 2 then walked back
out of Youth A’s room. Youth A denied Staff 2 making any
comments that made her feel uncomfortable, lingering in Youth
A’s room or touching Youth A. Youth A stated Staff 2 no longer
works at the facility.
Youth A described Staff 1 walking into her room several times
without announcing himself or knocking on the door. Youth A
stated she filled out a recipient rights complaint because staff are
not supposed to do safety checks that way and it is an invasion of
her privacy. Youth A described laying on her bed or being in the
shower when Staff 1 has walked into her room. Youth A stated
Staff 1 would look at her, sometimes say hi, then close the door.
Youth A denied Staff 1 making any comments that made her feel
uncomfortable, lingering in Youth A’s room or touching Youth A.
Youth A stated Staff 1 now works in a different area of the facility.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed face to face at the
facility, separately on December 6, 2023. They both denied any
staff completing safety checks without announcing themselves
and knocking on the door. Youth C reported she has been in the
shower when she has heard staff knocking on the door. Youth C
stated she just pokes her head out and staff do their check then
close the door. Youth B and Youth C stated staff must see your
head and neck when doing a safety check. Youth B reported staff
must enter the room even if youth do not respond to make sure
the youth is safe. Youth B and Youth C denied seeing Staff 1 or
Staff 2 enter Youth A or any other youths’ room without
announcing themselves or knocking on the door.
Staff 1 was interviewed via telephone on December 11, 2023.
Staff 1 described knocking three times on Youth A’s door saying,
“hey I’m doing a check,” and Youth A did not respond. Staff 1
3

stated he opened the door to do a head and neck check on Youth
A and Youth A was fully clothed sitting in the shower area. Staff 1
reported Youth A became mad Staff 1 was doing a check and
asked for a female staff. Staff 1 stated after Youth A became
upset Staff 1 asked for a female staff to complete the checks.
Staff 1 denied completing checks on Youth A or any youth without
announcing himself or knocking on the door. Staff 1 reported he
could not recall ever seeing any staff enter a youth’s room without
knocking or telling the youth a check was being done.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on December 11, 2023.
Staff 2 denied ever completing unannounced checks on any youth
while working at the facility. Staff 2 stated during training staff are
told they must complete checks even if a youth does not say
anything to ensure the youth is safe in their room. Staff 2 denied
ever seeing any staff enter a youths’ room without announcing
themselves or knocking.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There were two disciplinary actions
for attendance issues and Staff 1 completed training in
June and July of 2023.
• Staff 2’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 2 completed training in May and June of 2023.
• Recipient Rights Complaint form completed by Youth A
regarding Staff 1: Complaint is Staff 1 violated Youth A’s
privacy by entering Youth A’s room when she is in the
bathroom and laying down. Youth A requested for female
staff to complete checks. The complaint does not indicate
Staff 1 entered the room without announcing himself or
knocking.
• Documented Discussion with Staff 1 by Manager dated
12/11/23: Policy review and education done in regard to
checking on youth who are in the shower, especially if the
gender is different.
• Standard Operating Procedure: Lotus Program – Resident
Safety Checks Policy: Policy states, “If the resident is in
their bathroom/shower at the time the check is being
completed: A staff of the same gender should knock on the
door, indicate it is time for a check, and visually see the
individual. If a resident is in the shower, it would be
sufficient to see just the head/neck of the resident and not
their full body. It is NOT sufficient for the resident to simply
say they are okay – you must physically see at minimum
the resident’s head and neck.”
4

Analysis Although there were no findings that staff sexually abused Youth
A or failed to knock on Youth A’s door when walking in on Youth
A, the facility is found in noncompliance as the safety check
completed on Youth A while she was in the shower was in
violation of the agency’s Resident Safety Checks Policy as the
policy requires a staff of the same gender to complete the required
check.
Technical Assistance:
It is recommended the agency review the Resident Safety Checks
Policy to determine if updates should be made to allow a staff of
the opposite gender to complete checks on a youth in the shower
when a same gender staff is not available. The agency should
also consider updating the policy to include number of times a
staff member should announced themselves and knock on a
youths’ door prior to entering to provide clarification for staff.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
